I'm asking because I'm now using a separate partition for /tmp (fstab already changed, will take effect on reboot), but I want to delete all files in the "old" /tmp directory before that.
you'll need to delete them .. preferably after reboot - or in single-user mode (runlevel 1)
how do I get into runlevel 1 after reboot?
choose recovery mode from the grub screen  ... or you can type this now.  sudo telinit 1  (after closing your programs down)
to return to runlevel 2 after that.  sudo telinit 2
though, you'll need to mount /tmp first.  sudo mount  -a
but then I can't access the current /tmp directory anymore, whose content I want to delete?!
you should carry out the procedure like this .. step into runlevel 1, clear /tmp, mount /tmp and then return to runlevel 2
Oh, got you now. One last question: do I have to set the permissions of the /tmp folder *before* mounting the new /tmp?
errm, no, you need to change permissions on the partition you want to mount at /tmp .. mount it somewhere temporarily and then .  sudo chmod +t /that/mount_point
thanks a lot for your patience. I'll try that.
the next time you mount that device somewhere, the mount point (which in your case is /tmp) - will automatically assume the permissions of the partition.
